nodes.bodyText: Formatting looks odd, check the whole class.
Thanks, I have the formatter disable by default
Since I have to merge the input with the response, I prefer to avoid encode/decode step and perform the merge programatically
I prefer to have such annotations outside of the method, to favour readability.

yes, but as a generic rule the annotation should in lowest possible scope to prevent other unchecked casting to be unnoticed, in any case, I think that here an instance of will be desirable, so editing it
Use constants
sure, thanks

If you are addressing results of a JsonPath query, it will/should always be an array.
I don't fully understand the copying of values much, just return the json as-is that comes back from the rest service call.

The resulf of the rest invocation needs to be merged into the json tree, in order json queries to be performed over it.
The point is that details of the conversion are hidden into this object, so neither serverless no handler needs to be changed if the model structure change, just this object (or a new object that implements bifunction can be defined and invoked by the generator)

Ok, what I'm thinking is that it would be better for SW to deal with this via a script task that does this, than having this code in /jbpm/process/instance. Reason being is that SW should be able to do this independently of the bpmn2 processes for example. Or allow for SW to overwrite this class if possible, so it can evolve this independently

SW is specifying that this class should be used when populating the workitem with parameters
I think this is cleaner that forcing the sw writer to introduce a script task
Please read #778 (comment)

Are we exposing this to users in public api? If so it could also be used insides script expressions which is nice.
I would change it tho so it can be used easier, for example JsonPathResolver.resolve(....). much easier to deal w/ in expressions as such

This is not a public API. And even if it was, it is implementing a well known interface defined in jdk8, users familiar with utils.function package will probably expect an apply as public method in this case(but it does not matter since it is not public)
Please note that this class is for now specific to SW, since it is dealing with json path resolution

If its specific to SW then it should be in the jbpm/jbpm-serverless-workflow package and not in /jbpm/process/instance impl IMO. Again since IMO this can be set as a expression or in script task it would be nice to do that as SW can evolve independently.
I really do not care if it uses a well or not well known interface or not :) My concern is about usability.

I first put this class in sw project, but it turns out that classes there are not used at runtime, thats the only reason this class was add to flow, but I agree is not the better place. The goal of doing so is that this class should be in classpath at runtime
Class has been moved to serverless-workflow-runtime project (so can be edited by SW developers). It now implementes a well defined interface rather than the generic one

Don't get this:

It seems very workflow specific , but then again in new version the queries are enclosed in '{{' and '}}'.
Data passed to functions even in SW are not always expressions. It can be custom JSON objects as well.
This seems not useful for BPMN2 scenarios no?
'

This is code is not SW specific. This code is replacing parameters in the endpoint. JAX-RS convention is to include the path parameters to be replaced between {} (this is not related at all with json path, json path details are  handled by json specific class JsonPathResolver)
This behaviour applies both for POJO/Json parameters, both for BPMN/SW.
The code is not assuming POJO/Json, but it is relying in whatever is passed in the parameters of the workitem (concrete value, field name resolver, json path resolver). The point is that the handler delegates the resolution of the paramter value in the objects that are generated by the parser.

Ok. There are things missing here like accept headers, read timeouts, content type etc etc. Also expecting a hard-coded password in the workflow markup is something noone is going to really use as its pretty much only for demos I assume.
I hardly think that even for a demo anyone out there that still uses hard-coded passwords in their apps is even thinking about moving to a serverless architectures. wdyt?

RestTaskHadled needs evolution (as the SW flow ;)). I think at this stage we should care about the contract (aka how the serverles parser fills the work node item)
Content type is assumed to be json (is going to be different in any case?)
Headers can be specified as a parameter of the workitem (as method, user and password)
I agree that password for basic authentication needs to be at least encrypted (which encryption?)
Security constraints should be handled by injected configuration properties, please see: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1GgAEAAoiBWsQ3zDKsW_w_Uml4cg5C5dnG6tlGQZlY0g/edit#heading=h.9qnfgrgjxwzl
There's a JIRA for that: https://issues.redhat.com/browse/KOGITO-3160
Wonder since this defines workitem we can have a generic getWorkitemNode(....) method that can handle any future workitems that we might expose in kogito like this one.
I think parameters will be different depending on the work item type, probably some of this code can be moved to a common method, but most parameters names will differ.
Yeah, it can also be custom JSON data.

Yes, I added that comment to indicate that, when JSON pojo support is added to SW, a new Supplier that deals with POJO can be added here.
Thats the point of this parameter, through the Supplier (that generates a piece of code) the SW indirectly told the handler (wihtout having to change the handler code) how to resolve parameters (POJO or Json)
Why is this generated programmatically instead of being a template?
I asked myself the same thing.
because ServiceTaskDescriptor is not using template either. I can use template, but the generated code is going to be the same
I'd prefer to move as much code as possible to templates, especially new code :)
yes, Ill move to template
done
WorkItemNodeVisitor changes has been formatted now
formatted
formatted
to be honest, I dont think it is realistic to expect that a user name and password would be stored as the workitem paramenter, AKA bpmn model.

me neither, but this is what is already happening in v7 version of the rest handler. We need to discuss which is the best approach for passing password to handler, but it can be perfectly part of another JIRA, this one is already too big.
I think you might want to check value != null or it will throw NPE
Checked, returning null literal expr in that case
Any reason we are not sending json here as well? For SW at least the content type should always be application/json.

Line 108 is a GET or DELETE call, so there is no body, unlike POST or PUT call.
Json output is handled by ResultTaskResultHandler implementation provided as ResultHandler parameter. In the case of the example JsonPathResultHandler, now located in serverless-worflow-runtime project
What is the purpose of creating a separate work item handler for each process? A separate vertX client for each of them?
Yes, and also to reuse the same vertx instance (which is injected)

I think in jbpm it is a good convention to end all Work Item handlers with *WorkItemHandler suffix, i.e. RestWorkItemHandler. This way it is easier to distinguish them from SAX Parser handlers for example.
you are right, I'll rename it
I know it is just a template but still would be good to name it xxxRestWorkItemHandler, both the constructors and the name of the class.
yep
Unnecessary changes.
